# Discord Chat Analysis for ðŸ’»â”‚developers

## 1. Summary
The discussion primarily focused on technical aspects of Hyperfy app development. Key topics included:

- Script execution behavior in Hyperfy, with clarification that code runs on both server and client sides simultaneously, requiring conditional checks (`world.isClient` and `world.isServer`) to control execution context.
- A music player app that pulls playlists from Audius was discussed, with plans for future features like trending categories and synchronized listening zones.
- Material linking in Hyperfy was explored, particularly how duplicated objects share materials by default, requiring the `linked = false` property to enable individual material modifications.
- Server-client communication was explained, including how to detect when players enter or leave a world using event listeners.
- A confetti popper implementation was troubleshooted, resolving an issue where state changes (hover/cooldown) affected all instances instead of individual objects.
- The importance of the world folder structure for backup/restore functionality was mentioned, along with automatic mesh optimization through linking.

## 2. FAQ
Q: How can the app still be updating if no one is in the world? (asked by Lastraum - theforgecore.xyz) A: Code runs on both the server and the clients, the server is always running so you can have things like plants growing over time (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Is it exemplified in the docs anywhere that code runs on server even without an isServer block? (asked by Lastraum - theforgecore.xyz) A: Scripts execute on both server and clients, with server executing first on boot and clients running after receiving initial snapshot (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Is there a way for the server to know when a client has left and stop doing something? (asked by Lastraum - theforgecore.xyz) A: Yes, using world.on('leave', e => {}) event listener on the server (answered by Ashxn)
Q: Why do all my confetti poppers share the same state when I add multiple to the world? (asked by Gert-Jan Akerboom) A: Duplicated apps share the same materials by default, you need to set mesh.linked = false (answered by .hyp shaman and Valiant)

Helper: Ashxn | Helpee: Lastraum - theforgecore.xyz | Context: Explaining server/client code execution | Resolution: Provided code examples and explanation of world.isClient/world.isServer checks
Helper: Ashxn | Helpee: Lastraum - theforgecore.xyz | Context: Detecting when players leave a world | Resolution: Provided code example using world.on('leave') event listener
